subject: RE: [junit] Detecting failure in tearDown()
msgSnippet: In a similar, but simpler version of a previous poster, is there anything wrong (philosophically or technically) with the following class? public MyTest
messageBody:
In a similar, but simpler version of a previous poster, is there anything
wrong (philosophically or technically) with the following class?

public MyTest extends TestCase {
private boolean cleanUp;

MyTest(String s) {
super(s);
}

public void setUp() {
cleanUp = false;
}

public void testSomething() throws Exception {
/*
*
* Some code + assertions
*
*
* And after every assertion has passed . . .
*/

cleanUp = true;
}

public void tearDown() {
if (cleanUp) {
// do it
}
}
}


-----Original Message-----
From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...]
Sent: Thursday, October 30, 2003 3:32 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Detecting failure in tearDown()


jlindwall wrote:

> I'd like to be able to determine in tearDown() whether or not the
> test succeeded (eg, success, fail, or error).
>
> If you're curious why: If the test failed I'd like to leave the
> database in it's current state to assist in manually determining what
> went wrong. If the test succeeded I'd like to cleanu p the db.
>
> Using the standard runner I don't see any way to do this. Do I have
> to subclass the runners to add this feature?

Either subclass the test runner or, if you know any AOP, use an aspect
to do it. You're changing the behavior of runBare(), so I don't see any
alternative that doesn't lead to massive duplication.

Good luck.
